twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: 5 buffet myths that need to die. As someone who runs one, let me set the record straight:
thread_structure: 5 buffet myths that need to die. As someone who runs one, let me set the record straight:
Myth 1: 'Food sits out for hours' Reality: We rotate every 20-30 mins. Strict time stamps. Health code isn't optional.
Myth 2: 'Lower quality ingredients' Reality: We buy from the same suppliers as upscale restaurants. Volume = better pricing, not worse quality.
Myth 3: 'It's all frozen' Reality: 80% made fresh daily. Our cooks arrive at 5am. We have scratch kitchens.
Myth 4: 'Buffets are dying' Reality: Post-pandemic comeback is real. People missed variety and value. We're busier than 2019.
Myth 5: 'Owners get rich' Reality: Food cost is 35%, labor is 30%, overhead is 25%. Margins are razor thin. This is volume business.
Buffets work because we master logistics, waste management, and speed. It's actually harder than a la carte.
Next time you visit a buffet, you're seeing military-level food operations. Respect the craft.

thread_structure: After watching 10,000+ customers, I can predict your buffet strategy in the first 30 seconds. Here are the 7 types:
1. The Scout - walks the entire buffet twice before taking a single item. Analyzes options. Strategic. Respectable.
2. The Beeliner - knows exactly what they want. Straight to crab legs or prime rib. Ignores everything else. Efficient.
3. The Sampler - takes 1 spoonful of literally everything. Plate looks like a food rainbow. Living their best life.
4. The Salad Faker - loads up greens first. Returns 3 times for 'just a little more' mac and cheese. We see you.
5. The Dessert Firster - hits the sweets immediately. Unconventional but honest. No judgment here.
6. The Maximizer - stacks food like Jenga. Physics-defying plate architecture. Usually gets a second plate anyway.
7. The Grazer - 6-8 small trips. Different items each time. Actually the smartest strategy for trying everything.
Which one are you? (And yes, you can be different types on different days. We contain multitudes.)

twitter_content_templates.hook_tweet: Did the math: Ordering our buffet items a la carte would cost $47. We charge $16.99. Here's how we make it work:
thread_structure: Did the math: Ordering our buffet items a la carte would cost $47. We charge $16.99. Here's how we make it work:
1. Volume purchasing. We buy in bulk. 500 lbs of chicken gets a very different price than 50 lbs.
2. Labor efficiency. One cook manages 8 items vs. 8 cooks making individual orders. Math works out.
3. Waste reduction. We track data religiously. Know exactly what to prep. Less waste = lower cost.
4. Speed of service. No wait times. No servers. Lower labor cost passed to you.
5. Beverage margins. Yeah, the soda helps. But you're still getting incredible value on food.
We make money on volume, not margins. 500 customers at $3 profit beats 100 at $12 profit.
This is why buffets work. It's not magic. It's operations.
